snippet: Every autumn, the government drafts about a million people — including doctors, teachers and other professionals — to pick cotton, providing free labor for the world’s fifth-largest cotton exporter.
abstract: Uzbekistan government drafts roughly million people to pick cotton every year during fall harvest, providing free labor for world's fifth-largest cotton exporter; rights advocates have criticized system, made possible by cloistered and repressive society, as being continuation of cotton industry's history of forced labor.

byline.original: By MANSUR MIROVALEV and ANDREW E. KRAMER
byline.contributor: Mansur Mirovalev reported from Samarkand, and Andrew E. Kramer from Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan.

lead_paragraph: Every autumn, the government drafts about a million people — including doctors, teachers and other professionals — to pick cotton, providing free labor for the world’s fifth-largest cotton exporter.

headline.main: In Uzbekistan, the Practice of Forced Labor Lives On During the Cotton Harvest
headline.print_headline: In Uzbekistan, the Practice of Forced Labor Lives On During the Cotton Harvest
